text: Well, Morena, everyone, to start the meeting off, could I ask Shane if we start the meeting off with a karakia? Tēnā koutou katoa.

text: Kei aku rangatira kua raungi kama i runga i tēnei papakōrero, tēnā koutou. Kei ngā kai kaunihara, ngā kai mahi o te kaunihara o Waipa, tēnā koutou tātou katoa.  Ka rere anō rāna, mihi ki a koe. Jim Tremita, tō tātou kaumātua, mihi ana ki a koe rā. Aho ana rā hei, tīmata whē ngā tātou mahi. E papa e rangi, e papa e rangi. Tēnei tō pia, tēnei tō ariki tāuira, kai tū whakaotinuku, kai tū whakaotira. Tau ana mai te mana, te ihi, te tapu, ki runga ki ngā iwi kua rauka maine i runga i tēnei papakōrero i tēnei ata.  Tauana mai te mana, te ihi, te tapu, a ku ngā mātāpono, e manawanuitia ana, te aroha, te kotahitanga, te mahi tahi. Ke haere ake nei e nei tū āhuatanga, tēnei hui o mātou, otira te rohangātū o tēnei rā, tēnei wiki, tēnei marama. Tēnā, takahia rā, nea hou, tūturu owhiti whakamaua, kia tīna. Tīna.  Haumiä, huiä, taikkiä!

text: Yeah. Excellent. So what determines the  The cemeteries that are in this project for preparing concept plans for the council cemeteries is the ownership. So the scope's been determined to be the cemeteries that are owned and administered by the council. So that's, as you said, there's 10 public cemeteries across the district. And what we are keen to do at this early stage is understand from mana whenua how you would like us to engage with you on this project. We know that obviously,  while there's urupā, the cemeteries are important to mana whenua mātauaka in terms of places where whānau are buried, but also potentially in terms of important sites, sites of significance. So we're really keen to ensure that we are engaging the way you would like us to engage on that project. We've got a plan that looks in June to go out to the public with an online survey to get initial thoughts  I will then enter into, and we're doing some engagement with the RSA, Grey Power, other groups, and then we will look into drafting those plans and then taking those to community board, back to Ngāui Tūpū towards the end of the year, and then up to service delivery early next year for endorsement to then go out for another round of engagement on their draft plans themselves. So, I think there's real potential at the moment when we look at our network.  There's been an attempt to ensure there's things like water provision for tikanga, important tikanga, but in terms of any other sort of cultural infrastructure, there's nothing. So there's a lot of opportunity through design, through signage, through perhaps mahi toi, through planting to make these spaces more welcoming in terms of for iwi and hapū. But I think also,  Just the basic visitor. Some of the other things we've identified is there's a lack of shade and seating and other things that are really important to ensure that they are places where people can go and spend time comfortably. Thanks, Anna.

text: Yeah, thanks. Just to  Question, I noticed that you've got the Tokanui Cemetery as part of, on that list somewhere, I seem to recall seeing it. Because I recall when we had to address that,  Everyone denied any ownership, any responsibility for it, and it defaulted to the Conservation Board, under the auspices of the Conservation Board. But I think its location in the local community sort of kept it within the WIPA discussion anyway. It never even got to the Conservation Board to be discussed at all. It was just one of those default things.  So that's the first thing, where does that fit in this list? Because we have a strong interest in that Ulupa and how it's managed. Because it was on land that was taken from our people under the Public Works Act and never returned.  And the other one is, we're talking about playgrounds, is Mangas Reserve, which is in Urupa. It is the cemetery. It has a playground on it that belongs to Waipaea District Council. So we have to have a wider context of thinking when we think about, do we have playgrounds on Urupa?  or other things on Urupa. text: No, I'm not. Hopefully I'm not. OK, Joe, can you just run us through this item, please? Kia ora koutou. So the district plan update is pretty busy. We at the moment are working on plan change 26, which is a compulsory government plan change.  We are proposing to put Plan Change 21 on hold and notify early next year to bring our notification date in line with Hamilton City. We are working on Plan Change 17, which is the Hautapu Industrial Zones. Draft Plan Change 23, Papakainga. So we have lit a contract out to an external consultant to do the scoping.  for the plan change and to keep that moving. We've had a private plan change 20 for the airport northern precinct extension come in and that's currently on hold while we seek further information. At the same time, we've got the Carter flats, Carter's flat plan change underway, which is plan change 19.  And we have a number of private plan changes currently in discussion. Nothing lodged yet, but it's looking like we will get some private plan changes in between July and September. The share for plan change 26, which is the compulsory government plan change. And it's the one that requires us to allow for intensification.  in all residential zones within the urban boundaries of Cambridge, Te Amutu and Kehekehe. We are currently in the process of writing the plan change and we'll be looking to go out for limited iwi consultation at the end of this month. My apologies up front, it's not how I like to do consultation, but the timeframe the government has given us is that we must notify  on the 20th of August. We had a JMA hui last week, and it was proposed that consultation can keep occurring after notification. So I would be looking for the policy team to keep working with iwi to address any issues that have come up out of the plan change.  We will be having qualifying measures. So we are looking to exempt some residential areas from these medium density residential standards. We will be using the updated flood mapping as one of the qualifying areas. We are looking at heritage character areas. Any qualifying measures that we do has to be done on a site by site basis.  So we are unable to do a blanket exemption. We have to justify it site by site. We are receiving infrastructure review reports at the end of June, and we are looking to use those to support the outcome from Te Tūwhawhaimana. So ultimately,  and the protection of the Waikato River and the river catchment will be the number one priority of the plan change. And that is in line with Waikato District Council and Hamilton City Council. So, the three councils are working together to use a vision and strategy as basically the top aim, the umbrella under which the plan changes sit.  and having front of mind at the start from the plan changes that it's the betterment and protection of the river. We can't enable anything that causes further degradation of the river. So that is plan change 26. So big plan change, not really supported by any of the councils who have to do it from the meetings I've been having, but we are just going to get it done.
speaker: ocookmunro

text: Thanks, Jo. Was there any questions of Jo in terms of those plan changes?

But nobody said anything about how that framework works, or where did it come from, or we understand where it came from, but what does it mean?  So I know, and I'm sure that others that are in Ngāi Topi would have looked at it and thought, well, what does that mean in a mātauranga framework? All you did was put in a whole lot of plans. And, you know, in all due respect, they were all iwi plans. And so, and you're talking te mana whenua.  about an iwi plan. We're not responsible for the iwi plan, and I don't know how many times I've said it. We're not responsible for them. They have a legislation to run by, and that's how they do their stuff in that framework. For us, we want to know what does it work? What does a framework look like for mana whenua? A Mataranga Māori framework look like? And because councils don't have one, because you work at a higher level. It's a higher level that you're doing. So it's all iwi stuff.  So where does the mana whenua fit in that iwi space, in that mātāranga framework? That's what I'm asking. So my question, and Stephen knew that's what I was getting at. So where does a mātāranga Māori fit into that framework? It doesn't.
speaker: gayleneroberts

text: I think if I'm going to try to respond to this, but the Mataranga Māori framework has actually gone through quite a bit of assessment from Ngāi Waiotopu, from our PCG members. We tried to develop it with PCG members and Mana Whenua PCG members only on the 16th of May. We went through actually this in detail.  to explain how that would be actually used as an evaluation tool. What we mentioned is that, like every other framework, those are directing questions. They are not the important part in the evaluation. The important part in the evaluation is the core of the discussion that comes actually with it. And this is really where  the implementability of those aspirations will actually be assessed, be almost dismantled and put together again. This is where the plan is really being put together. The Mataranga Maori framework, like the LTP framework, like the quantitative assessment framework, are only tools and mechanisms to direct those discussions to make sure that there is  a process in place, a structured process in place for this discussion to happen, and for each item, topic, key area, aspirations to be reviewed. So they are only a framework. What is really important is not what happens. What the structure is, is the content of those discussion. That's really where those framework will come alive. As they are, they are words on a piece of paper. We are providing direction to a real career role.  that we need to have on the 30th of June. That's how I see it. Those frameworks are only guiding tools. They're making sure and ensuring there is a true partnership going there, but we do not miss any key factors or key areas who are important to every person within the community. For me, they are guiding tools.  will make the plan. The discussion around it, the conflict, the disagreement, the agreement, that's what's going to make the plan.

text: Some of you will remember back in late 2019, I addressed the group around the possible use of marae as civil defence centres or community-led centres within our communities. And then COVID sort of got in the way and many marae closed and we weren't able to meet or anything.  I'm just wanting to pick up this work stream again now that COVID seems to be relaxing our colors and we're in orange and hopefully going to green soon, that we'll be able to pick up on this work stream and get some documentation and have some conversations around using Mirai's if we need to in an emergency as a CDC or a community-led center.  So my reason for coming back to you is just so that we can keep you informed and also to ensure that we get from you the right context for the maraes and the strategies that we will use to connect with them and have the conversations with them around collecting details.  I'm aware that some marae have not yet reopened after COVID and some are wanting to remain closed. I'm not quite sure, but that's where your information would be vital for me to gather the necessary information for me to contact the right people and to make sure we get the right information in the right places.

text: Thanks, Kathy. It's a good opportunity to touch base, isn't it? And it's interesting now, isn't it, that with COVID going on for as long as it has, probably for a couple of years almost now, it's easy to envisage that we could have the remnants of a pandemic in the community as it is now, and still get a flood.  where a marae might be quite comfortable with supporting a flood event on its own, it may not be suitable if there's still the pandemic in force at the same time. So it's gonna be a challenging time, I think, for marae to actually have that sort of discussion to know whether they're available for all civil defence emergencies or just some.

Those went very well. I'm yet to hear back from Makahitaki how well that went. And I think it's less than a dozen people at each site. And that's a peculiar kui putea because of the outbreaks of COVID in the Otorohanga district. There's still quite a bit of that going on there.  The numbers were very small, intimate, and recordings were captured by, I believe, by Waikato Tainui at Matangitaki and the Manipoto FM crew at Huiputea. Waiting to see where the links are so that we can share them around. But those were done on behalf of Huiputea, which is a protective measure for both sides, for both mana whenua and for our manukiri who would have come, of course, from  far north, tērā tērā. Noting too also that this year has been accounted by the Kingitanga as Te Tau o Tāwhiao, that this is the year of King Tāwhiao, and as much as he was born 200 years ago, not long after the attack on Mātakitaki.  born in the southern areas, and a little place called Orohokoikoia. For some of you who might be familiar with the Madonna Falls, past Te Kuiti on your way to Taumaranui, an area adjacent or around about there. text: Well, no one's been appointed for those. There's no one. And I'll just make sure that Raukawa are aware that they can appoint someone as well.
speaker: garyknighton

text: Yep, there we go. Thank you. Okay. Thanks, Kayleigh.
speaker: gayleneroberts

text: Can I just note, Your Worship, just Hopai and Harold, we're just trying to contact you. We've got a few local issues that we want to talk to you about. So when you see my number come up on your phone.
speaker: garyknighton

text: Right.
speaker: garyknighton

text: Yep. Oh, block it. Yeah.
speaker: garyknighton

text: No, anytime Gary, just get hold of Kathy if you wish and sort out a time if you need to meet.  Yeah, I think they probably don't need you, Jim.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Just some smaller local issues. Skateboard packs in Maunganui Reserve. Just a few issues relating to those that we wanted to catch up with Haukai and Harold on. Okay.
speaker: garyknighton

text: All right. Well, if there's no further items, thank you very much for your attendance. I'm sorry that we can't  break for lunch now and share food together, but I'll hand over to Shane to close the meeting.
speaker: jimmylchreest

text: Kia ora te marino, kia whakapapa pounamu te moana, kia tere te karohi rohe. A ko tō tātou hoa haere, haere ake nei, ko te rangi Māori. Tūturu owhiti whakamaua, kia tīna, tīna, haumi e hui e tākei.
speaker: shaneteruki
